section1.title: KAŠTEL
section1.content:
Pazinski Kaštel danas slovi za najočuvaniju srednjovjekovnu utvrdu središnje Istre, a najstariji sačuvani pisani trag o postojanju Kaštela nalazimo u potvrdnoj darovnici Otona II. od 7. lipnja 983. godine u kojoj nosi naziv Castrum Pisinum.
Prvotni se Kaštel najčešće u literaturi opisuje kao jednostavna, jaka konstrukcija poput izduženoga pravokutnika s prizemljem i s dva kata, s prislonjenom kvadratičnom kulom i zidinama koje su, uz druge građevine, obuhvaćale i kaštelansku kapelu posvećenu Madoni i pripadajući mali zvonik. Na njemu su očuvani tragovi dugog građevinskog razvitka jer je mnogobrojnim dogradnjama, pregradnjama i adaptacijama Kaštel višestruko prilagođavan i osuvremenjivan primarno za potrebe obrane, a sekundarno i za stambene potrebe. 
Najveće je preinake Kaštel doživio tijekom obnove u 15. i 16. stoljeću prvenstveno uvjetovane promjenama u načinu ratovanja, odnosno prelaskom s hladnog na vatreno oružje čija je upotreba na području Pazinštine prvi put zabilježena 1463. godine. Planovima obnove u 16. stoljeću bilo je zamišljeno jačanje utvrde izgradnjom bastiona na strateški najvažnijim mjestima (ispred kvadratne i polukružne kule), što zbog visokih troškova nije realizirano. Usprkos tome, Kaštel u tom periodu dobiva unutrašnje dvorište s cisternom, a dograđena mu je i polukružna kula na sjeveroistoku. Zidni je plašt Kaštela perforiran malim otvorima i mašikulama u prizemlju i na prvom katu dok je na sjeverozapadnom, sjevernom i istočnom krilu te na polukružnoj kuli, u visini drugog kata, pridodana ophodna galerija izgrađena iz opeke radi boljeg nadzora okolnog prostora i obrane. Pročelje Kaštela također je urešeno bogatim gotičkim profilacijama navedenog razdoblja. U 17. stoljeću, 1639. godine, na drugom katu polukružne kule izvedena je kapelica posvećena Blaženoj Djevici Mariji s drvenim oltarom koji je u 18. stoljeću zamijenjen mramornim.  
Smirivanjem i postupnim prestankom ratnih opasnosti u 18. i 19. stoljeću radovi na Kaštelu bili su prvenstveno vezani uz poboljšanje uvjeta stanovanja. Tada su otvoreni brojni prozorski otvori na unutrašnjoj i vanjskoj fasadi Kaštela. Kvadratna kula, do 19. stoljeća najprepoznatljiviji simbol pazinskog Kaštela, tada je snižena na razinu ostalih krovova, a na istočnom je pročelju dozidan toranj s urom i preslicom. Uz navedeno, u tom su vremenskom periodu poduzete i određene mjere koje se mogu opisati kao razgrađivanje utvrde – uz snižavanje visine kvadratne kule i otvaranje prozorskih otvora, srušeni su nepotrebni bedemi, zatrpani prokopi prema gradu, uklonjeni pokretni mostovi te uređene sobe i zamijenjena stubišta. Kaštel tada poprima isključivo stambenu funkciju.

section2.title: KAŠTEL KAO SREDIŠTE PAZINSKE KNEŽIJE
section2.content: Kao utvrda, pazinski je Kaštel stoljećima bio središte Pazinske knežije (tal. Contado di Pisino, njem. Grafschaft Mitterburg), posebnog područja pod upravom pazinskog Kapetana sačinjenog od Kaštela kao središta i okolnih mjesta sukladno Urbaru.\nPazinsku knežiju uspostavio je u 12. stoljeću Mainard od Schwarzburga, posjednik kule Črni grad iznad današnjeg Roča. Po izumruću porodice ženidbenim je vezama 1175. godine Knežija došla u posjed goričkih grofova, a 1374. godine na osnovi nasljednog ugovora prešla u ruke Habsburgovaca u čijem je vlasništvu ostala do druge polovice 18. stoljeća. Za Habsburgovce je knežija bila prvenstveno izvor prihoda te su ju često davali u zakup ili zalagali za dobivene zajmove pa se tijekom stoljeća izmijenilo mnogo plemenitaških obitelji kao upravitelja Kaštela. O nekoliko njih i danas svjedoče grbovi uklesani u fasade Kaštela, na samom pročelju ili istočnoj fasadi.\nPazinsku su knežiju Habsburgovci prodali 1766. godine za 240.000 forinti Antoniu Ladrechiju Montecuccoliju. Propašću Mletačke republike 1797. godine prestaje postojati i Pazinska knežija. Sam je Kaštel, ipak, do kraja Drugog svjetskog rata bio vlasništvo talijanske obitelji Montecuccoli.

section1.title: THE CASTLE
section1.content:
The Pazin Castle is known as the most preserved medieval fortresses in Central Istria. Oldest written trail of its existence can be found within the deed of gift by Emperor Oton II dated on June 7th 983 by which the Castle carried the name Castrum Pisinum.
The Castle from that period is often described as a simple, strong rectangular-shaped construction with the ground floor and two upper floors, a square tower leaning to it and walls which, besides other buildings, encompass the Chapel dedicated to the Madonna and a small bell tower. Traces of long construction development are preserved on the Castle because it was multiply adapted and modernised by numerous upgrades, reconstructions and adaptations, primarily for the purpose of defense and secondarily, for housing needs. 
The most notable modifications to the Castle were made during its reconstruction in the 15th and 16th century. They were mostly conditioned by the changes in warfare, i.e. changes from cold weapons to firearms whose first usage in the area surrounding Pazin was recorded in 1463. Renewal plans from the 16th century  included consolidation of the fortress by building bastions on strategically important places (in front of the square and semicircular tower) which was, at the end, not realised due to high costs. Despite that, in that period the inner courtyard was built with a cistern and the semicircular tower in the Northeast. The walls were perforated with small apertures and machicolation in the ground  floor and first floor levels. A gallery overlooking the surrounding area was build on the second floor level on the Northwest, North and East and the semicircular tower. Facade of the Castle is also abundantly decorated with Gothic profilations. During the 17th century, in 1639, a Chapel dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary was build on the second floor of the semicircular tower with a wooden altar which was replaced by a marble one in the 18th century.  
Pacification and gradual ending of war danger during the 18th and 19th century affected the works on the Castle which were, at that point, directed towards improvement of housing needs. Numerous windows were opened on the inner and outer facades, while a tower with a clock and bell tower were added in the East part of the Castle. Besides mentioned, in that period in time certain measures which can be described as disintegration of the fortress were conducted, such as lowering of the height of the square tower, window opening, demolition of the unnecessary bulwarks, backfilling of the canals towards the city, removing of the movable bridges, room decoration and staircase renovation. From that period on, the Castle exclusively acquired the status of a residence.

section2.title: CASTLE AS THE CENTER OF THE PAZIN COUNTY
section2.content: As a fortress, throughout centuries the Castle was the centre of the Pazin County (Contado di Pisino or Grafschaft Mitterburg), a seperate administrative unit under the management of the Count. It consisted of the Castle, as its centre, and the surrounding areas, according to the Urbar.\nPazin County was established in the 12th century by Mainard from Schwarzburg (Meinhard von Schwarzenburg), the owner of the Cernigrad (Cernogradus) near Roč. After his family extinct, due to marital bonds, the County became the property of the Counts of Gorizia in 1175. In 1374, following the inheritance contract, it became the ownership of the Habsburgs who ruled ove rit until the second half of the 18th century. For them, the County was mainly a source of income and was often leased. During the long centuries, numerous noble families are known to have been the managers of the Castle. Coats of arms engraved into the entrance and the east facade of the Castle are their testimonies. \nIn 1776 Pazin County was sold by the Habsburgs to Antonio Ladrechi Moncetuccoli for 240000 forints. In 1797, by the decline of the Venetian Republic, the County also ceased to exist. The Castle, though, remained under the authority of the Montecuccoli's until the end of World War II.
